PERSONA:
meet karen thompson, a 72-year-old retired school administrator living with her 75-year-old husband, john, in coos bay, oregon, a small coastal town in the pacific northwest. born and raised in nearby portland, karen earned a master's degree in education from the university of oregon, later spending 35 years working for the coos bay school district, with 10 years as a high school principal.

karen is a lifelong republican and considers herself a conservative, primarily due to her fiscally conservative views on budgeting and education policy, shaped by her experience managing school district finances. she and john have been married for 48 years and have two grown children and four grandchildren, all of whom live in the pacific northwest.

the thompsons own a two-story home in the eastside neighborhood of coos bay, which they bought 20 years ago for $250,000. their home is now valued at around $450,000, a significant portion of their net worth. karen and john also own a vacation home in nearby bandon, where they spend a few months each year.

karen is an active member of the local community, volunteering at the coos bay animal shelter and participating in monthly clean-up initiatives along the coast. she attends church services at the coos bay united methodist church with her husband. karen's family income is around $120,000 per year, primarily from john's pension and their retirement investments, as well as some rental income from their bandon vacation home, which they occasionally rent to tourists during the peak season.

karen is a frequent user of the internet and is active on facebook, where she follows local news and keeps in touch with friends and family. she uses online banking and shops online occasionally but prefers local businesses whenever possible. her economic concerns include the rising cost of living, particularly housing costs, which she believes are pricing out local families, and the economic impact of proposed changes to the state's tax policies on schools and community programs.

while karen generally supports the local economy and state policies focusing on education, environmental conservation, and job creation, she is critical of government overreach and opposes policies that she perceives as stifling small businesses and individual freedoms.
